Award.AwardTitle: AccessSTEM: The Northwest Alliance for Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics-Phase II (AccessSTEM2)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The "AccessSTEM: The Northwest Alliance for Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics - Phase II (AccessSTEM2)" project will increase the associate, baccalaureate, and graduate science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) degree attainment of individuals with disabilities in the Seattle, WA region. The primary institution, the University of Washington (UW), is partnering with Bellevue Community College (BCC), Seattle Central Community College (SCCC), and all high schools within the Seattle Public Schools system to accomplish this goal.

The AccessSTEM-Phase 2 Alliance will increase the associate, baccalaureate and graduate STEM degree attainment of students with disabilities by attending to the following four objectives:

1. Implement changes within awardee and partner postsecondary institutions (UW, BCC, SCCC) to make STEM programs more welcoming and accessible to students with disabilities (e.g., more accessible websites and science labs, STEM publications that encourage the participation of students with disabilities);

2. Create and expand engagement of stakeholders (precollege STEM educators, disability services, veteran associations, projects that broaden participation in STEM, and industry and career services) in fostering STEM education and careers that are welcoming and accessible to people with disabilities;

3. Implement evidence-based practices (e.g., mentoring, peer support, internships) to increase numbers of individuals with disabilities moving through critical junctures to STEM associate, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees and careers; and

4. Support and expand an online resource center that shares research and promising practices worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Washington (UW), with funding from the National Science Foundation Research in Disabilities Education program, hosted The Northwest Alliance for Students with Disabilities in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics—Phase II (AccessSTEM2), a comprehensive, multidisciplinary network of stakeholders with the goal to increase the quality and quantity of students with disabilities completing associate, baccalaureate, and graduate degrees in STEM and entering the STEM workforce.

Intellectual Merit: The DO-IT (Disabilities, Opportunities, Internetworking, and Technology) Center at the UW led AccessSTEM2, which was championed by the UW Office of Minority Affairs and Diversity and the College of Engineering. The UW engaged a Work Group established by 3 institutional partners: Bellevue Community College, Seattle Central Community College, and the Seattle Public Schools District. Topical partners represent 6 stakeholder groups—precollege STEM educators, postsecondary STEM educators, disability services, veteran associations, projects that broaden participation in STEM, and industry/career services.

Model: Grounded in research and practice, the AccessSTEM Student-Centered Community Building Model was created as a useful tool for organizing evidence-based practices and promising interventions for high school students, college students, and STEM professionals with disabilities. The model can be accessed at: www.washington.edu/doit/accessstems-student-centered-community-building-model.

Student Engagement: AccessSTEM2 students completed 144 internships in fields such as computing, accessible technology, robotics, environmental science, data analysis, forest science, library science, neural engineering, bioengineering, psychology, aeronautics, mechanical engineering, chemical engineering, electrical engineering, astronomy, biology, epidemiology, statistics, atmospheric science, animation. Forty students graduated high school and fifteen of those enrolled in college. Twelve vocational training certificates in STEM were received. Forty-three students completed a transfer degree or an associate’s degree in STEM, and nineteen of those transferred to the UW. Sixty-six students completed STEM baccalaureate degrees. Seventeen transferred to STEM graduate programs. Fourteen students received master’s degrees, and six students earned Ph.D.’s in STEM fields.

Additional Outreach: AccessSTEM2 engaged nearly 6,000 students with disabilities (and more than 700 parents) at workshops, transition-to-college fairs, activities on college campuses, and other events.

Products: AccessSTEMs disseminated more than 30,000 products, which are available for stakeholders through the AccessSTEM Website, (www.washington.edu/doit/programs/accessstem):

  • A book, Perspectives of STEM Students with Disabilities, which highlights the achievements of individuals with disabilities pursuing STEM: www.washington.edu/doit/perspectives-stem-students-disabilities.
  • An online publication called The STEM Lab: www.washington.edu/doit/programs/accesscollege/stem-lab/overview.
  • An online publication, Making STEM Accessible to Postsecondary Students with Disabilities, to empower educators to make STEM programs and support services welcoming and accessible to students with disabilities by applying evidence-based practices: www.washington.edu/doit/making-stem-accessible-postsecondary-students-disabilities.
  • A video, Equal Access: Universal Design of an Academic Department, about making postsecondary departments welcoming and accessible to students with disabilities: www.washington.edu/doit/videos/index.php?vid=65.
  • A proceedings document from the AccessSTEM2 Capacity Building Institute: www.washington.edu/doit/promoting-successful-participation-people-disabilities-stem-2014.
  • The AccessSTEM Knowledge Base, which contains more than 600 articles: www.washington.edu/doit/programs/accessstem/knowledge-base.
  • The brochure Accessible Science Equipment: www.washington.edu/doit/accessible-science-equipment.
  • The brochure Checklist for Making Science Labs Accessible to Students with Disabilities: www.washington.edu/doit/checklist-making-science-labs-accessible-students-disabilities.

In addition to book chapters, websites, and other publications, articles promoting the full inclusion of people with disabilities in STEM programs and careers developed and published by AccessSTEM2 staff appeared in the following journals:

  • Careers and the Disabled
  • Workforce Diversity for Engineering and Information Technology Professionals
  • ACM Transactions on Computing Education
  • Journal of Postsecondary Education and Disability
  • Closing the Gap
  • Journal of Science Education for Students with Disabilities
  • NeuroRehabilitation
  • Journal of Vocational Rehabilitation
  • Design for All
  • Review of Disability Studies
  • Dimensions
  • Japan Academy of Learning Disabilities
  • Information Technology and Disabilities Journal
  • Open Learning: The Journal of Open and Distance Learning

Communities of Practice (CoPs). The Community of Practice paradigm applied in AccessSTEM2 has origins in business. Within the CoPs, practitioners with common interests helped each other improve practices. They shared perspectives and expertise in their disciplines, provided suggestions for project activities and materials, promoted practices that support the project goal, and recruited new members. A total of 465 individuals participated in five groups: (1) STEM educators, (2) disability services personnel, (3) veterans-serving organizations, (4) leaders of projects that serve to broaden participation in STEM, and (5) industry and career services.

Broader Impacts: AccessSTEM2 ensures long-term impact because it

  • broadens the participation of people with disabilities in STEM academic programs and careers, including those who are also women, underrepresented minorities, and/or economically disadvantaged;
  • builds on existing networks and creates durable relationships among stakeholders in an integrated effort that enhances the infrastructure for research and education;
  • publishes transformational research and practices to enhance understanding and promote replication; and
  • puts into place structures that will sustain project impact after the project funding period has ended.

Transformational project outcomes benefit society by making STEM opportunities available to more citizens and by enhancing STEM fields with the talents and perspectives of people with disabilities.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/07/2017
Modified by: Sheryl Burgstahler

Seventeen transferred to STEM graduate programs. Fourteen students received master?s degrees, and six students earned Ph.D.?s in STEM fields. Additional Outreach: AccessSTEM2 engaged nearly 6,000 students with disabilities (and more than 700 parents) at workshops, transition-to-college fairs, activities on college campuses, and other events. A total of 465 individuals participated in five groups: (1) STEM educators, (2) disability services personnel, (3) veterans-serving organizations, (4) leaders of projects that serve to broaden participation in STEM, and (5) industry and career services.
